title: Don't silence graduation speakers: Fight hate speech with more speech
text:
CLOSE

We're quick to assume students want to silence those with views they think are harmful. But they're battling hate speech with more speech.

People hold up signs and shout while listening to speakers during a Rally Against Hate. (Photo: Josh Edelson, AP)

As graduation season approaches and commencement speakers are announced, universities are no doubt bracing for yet another season of controversy over the choice of speaker. And no wonder: A recurrent, troubling theme in the news media is that college students’ support for free speech is diminishing, especially when they find the speech offensive. In March, a Gallup/Knight Foundation survey found that a majority of students value diversity over free speech, and that nearly two-thirds think the First Amendment should not protect hate speech.

There is less media coverage, however, of survey data highlighting positive aspects of students’ reported experiences concerning both diversity and free speech. For example, in a 2016 Gallup/Knight survey, nearly three-fourths of students described the racial climate on their campus as excellent or good. These positive attitudes were shared by large majorities of Hispanic (75%), Asian (70%), and black (62%) students. Moreover, in the 2018 Gallup/Knight survey, only one out of four students overall said they have felt uncomfortable because of something that was said on campus about their race, ethnicity or religion and overwhelming majorities of students in all demographic and political categories say they are able to freely express their views.

More: Police must act fast to protect First Amendment rights: Robert Shibley

More: We need to restore trust in free speech. We're opening a new center to help: Napolitano

In September 2017, Buzzfeed News reported similarly encouraging results from what it described as “the first comprehensive survey of hate speech at higher education institutions since the 2016 election.” While that survey confirmed 154 hate speech incidents at more than 120 campuses around the country (out of the almost 5,000 total), “colleges typically responded to bias incidents quickly and to the satisfaction of their students ... In nearly every case, university presidents sent off mass emails con­demning the hate speech.” In short, rather than censoring hate speech, the universities responded with the classic “counterspeech” approach that is not only true to the First Amendment, but also effective in curbing hateful attitudes and actions. As Barack Obama has repeatedly told college and other audiences: “The strongest weapon against hateful speech is not repression; it is more speech — the voices of tolerance that rally against bigotry.”

So why the disconnect between students’ general satisfaction with the racial and free speech climates on their campuses, and their support for changing U.S. law to permit punishing hate speech? I think a major reason is that students underestimate the power of their own voices and other counterspeech in curbing hateful attitudes and actions, while overestimating the efficacy of censorship in doing so.

Many human rights activists in other countries that strictly enforce hate speech laws have endorsed the American approach, concluding that it is more effective, as have experts in international agencies. For example, in 2015, the European Commission Against Racism and Intolerance concluded that counterspeech and other non-censorial measures are “much more likely” than censorship “to prove effective in ultimately eradicating” hateful speech and conduct.

While hate speech and crimes are still too common in the U.S., they are swiftly and strongly condemned not only by those directly affected, but also by government officials, community lead­ers, and powerful social media campaigns like #BlackLivesMatter and #MeToo. This is hardly to say “Mission Accomplished” when it comes to endemic societal and individual biases. But it is proof positive that human rights activism has been flourishing despite — or even because of — the hateful, discriminatory speech and conduct.

Most encouragingly, marginalized populations are increasingly raising their voices and being taken seriously. Shaun Harper, Director of the University of Southern California’s Race and Equity Center, describes this development as “an unmuting of black collegians,” who are now “speaking more loudly” than ever “about the … racism they experience in classrooms and elsewhere.” Likewise, we recently have been witnessing the extraordinary “unmuting” of even much younger students to protest the gun violence that terrorizes their classrooms and lives.

More: My pro-free speech views made me the target of a smear campaign at Vassar College

POLICING THE USA: A look at race, media, justice

In contrast, extensive experience with hate speech laws in other mature democracies shows that they too often mute members of minority groups and their advocates. For example, the UN’s Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination concluded that hate speech laws “have been used to the detriment of” minority groups, and threaten “to curtail expressions of protest at injustice, social discontent or opposition.” One case in point: In 2016, a French court criminally convicted an LGBT rights leader, and saddled her with a fine of more than $2500, for labeling the leader of an anti-marriage equality group as a “homophobe.”

Moreover, there is no evidence that countries that enforce hate speech laws experience declines in the amount of either hateful speech or discriminatory behavior, and ample evidence to the contrary. Agnes Callamard, Director of Global Freedom of Expression at Columbia University, noted that European countries with strict hate speech laws recently have been “ravaged by intolerance and. . . increasing inequality,” as well as “rising levels of violence and hate.” Referring to the mounting anti-Semitic violence throughout Europe, on April 20, Israeli Independence Day, New York Times columnist Bret Stephens chillingly observed: “To be Jewish — at least visibly Jewish — in Europe is to live on borrowed time.”

Which brings us back to college students’ seemingly inconsistent attitudes, calling for censorship of hate speech while also feeling both more positive about the racial climate on their campuses, and more empowered to raise their voices against the still serious ongoing problems. I am hopeful that the two latter trends will ultimately persuade students that counterspeech — their own and others’ — is a “much more effective” strategy than censorship for promoting further positive change. The speech of these students and many others before them has brought us this far in the struggle for equal rights — and it has the power to take us even further.

Nadine Strossen, a constitutional law professor at New York Law School, is also the past President of the American Civil Liberties Union. Her book HATE: Why We Should Resist It with Free Speech, Not Censorship will be published in May by Oxford University Press.
